Bug.WithStack:
Build 05/19.
1) Open two windows 2) Open the java editor on the same java file in both windows 3) Go to a Explorer and open notepad on the java file 4) Make a change in the notepad version and save it 5) Click on one of the editors. The prompt "File has changed, do you want to load the changes?" appears. Say "yes" load the new file.
There are no errors but it doesn't load the changes. This only happens once you opened two editors on the same file. It seems to have something to do with the DocumentProvider and working copy.
This is a blocker for us (the WSAD Java Visual Editor) because we have this situtuation by default and we can't get validateEdit kind of stuff working because of this. Looking through the code, I'm guessing what is happening is that the AbstractTextEditor is doing a setInput with the FileInput. What happens under the covers is that the editor disconnects from the document and then reconnects back. I'm guessing that if there is no other editor open on the document, the disconnect frees the document and the connect gets a brand new one, which will get the current file contents. And if the document is shared, the disconnect simply decrements the inuse counter, and reconnect increments it again, but since the document didn't go away it uses the old contents. Bug.Summery: Doc: Team/Update doesn't complain if unable to proceed
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020521 - F1
When attempting to team/update a file on which an outgoing change was made, update does nothing, and doesn't surface it to the user.
Team/commit does complain if unable to proceed, would expect update to behave in a similar fashion. This is how CVS works. Team/Update will load all remote changes into your local working copy.
If you are using Team/Update and you want to see which files have outgoing changes, open the CVS console before performing the update. The console will show the results of the update (which files had mergable conflicts, which ones had unmergable conflicts and which ones have outgoing changes).
Word of warning: Only use Team/Update if you know CVS. If there are "real" conflicts (i.e. those that effect the same line of a file) then CVS will add markup to the file during the update. Resolving these conflicts in this manner is not pleasant.

Bug.Summery: ChangeToPerspectiveMenu Leaks
Bug.WithStack:
The ChangeToPerspectiveMenu is not being disposed. To recreate:
Take the F1 build, In the shortcut bar bring up the ChangeToPerspectiveMenu
From a memory profiler new instances of this menu are being created every time and not being released.
Nick, this problem has been here for a while recall our discussion about disposing popup menus and the different SWT behavior between Win and Motif when. (ie. one platform returns immediately while the other call waits until the menu has been processed) Need to create menu once for the window (can do so lazily). Need to ensure listeners do not inadvertently hang on to perspective instances. OK to hang onto descriptors, but ideally that should be avoided too. Changed PerspectiveContributionItem to use a menu manager instead of creating and managing the menu itself. Note that simply using MenuManager to create the menu each time will not fix the leak, since context menus hang around for the lifetime of the shell, unless they are set as the current menu of a control when it is disposed.
MenuManager actually caches the menu and returns it each time. It manages the menu item inside of it depending on the contribution items. No extra menu should be created now each time the menu is popup.

Bug.Summery: Find/Replace dialog overwrites Find string in dialog

Lines.Line: - open an editor (either text or Java)
- select a word
- type ^F to bring up the Find/Replace dialog
- your word is in the "Find:" field
- in the "Replace With:" field, type another word (for example, "splat")
- click on the "Replace" button
- open a text file with multiple instances of the string "foo".
- bring up the Find/Replace dialog
- type "bar" in the Replace With field
- now repeatedly click the "Replace/Find" button until all instances of "foo"
in the file have been replaced with "bar".
The bug: after replacing the last instance of "bar", the "Find:" string in the
dialog suddenly turns into "bar".
- open a text file with multiple instances of the string "foo".
- bring up the Find/Replace dialog
- type "bar" in the Replace With field
- click "Replace All"
The bug: the "Find:" string is now "bar".

Bug.WithStack:
20020521 (F1)
This is a regression - it was not a problem until very recent builds.
- open an editor (either text or Java) - select a word - type ^F to bring up the Find/Replace dialog - your word is in the "Find:" field - in the "Replace With:" field, type another word (for example, "splat") - click on the "Replace" button
The bug is that the "Find:" field in the dialog now contains the word "splat". This can be misleading if you then try to do another Find - particularly if the user did not notice that the Find text was replaced. They might think that the original search string was not found. It is also inconvenient for the user if they did notice that their original string is now gone, because they have to either type it in again to keep searching, or they have to go to the Find combo box to get it back.
Other places where this bug shows up: - open a text file with multiple instances of the string "foo". - bring up the Find/Replace dialog - type "bar" in the Replace With field - now repeatedly click the "Replace/Find" button until all instances of "foo" in the file have been replaced with "bar". The bug: after replacing the last instance of "bar", the "Find:" string in the dialog suddenly turns into "bar".
One more example: - open a text file with multiple instances of the string "foo". - bring up the Find/Replace dialog - type "bar" in the Replace With field - click "Replace All" The bug: the "Find:" string is now "bar".
